title: The Molecules of Life: Why Lettuce has LOTS of Protein and Carbs
description:
Does lettuce really have a bunch of carbs? What is a carbohydrate anyway? How are proteins formed? This video is a comprehensive introduction to macromolecules, including nucleic acids and lipids.
üëâ Want to support Biocinematics? https://www.patreon.com/biocinematics üëç

Teaching topics: Macromolecules, monomers/polymers, proteins, nucleic acids, carbohydrates, lipids, structural biology

Please consider SUBSCRIBING (it's free) to watch more science/biology animations. https://www.youtube.com/biocinematics

Discuss this video at: https://www.reddit.com/r/Biocinematics

0:00 Introduction
2:04 Monomers and Polymers
4:21 Proteins
7:19 Nucleic Acids
9:08 Carbohydrates
11:17 Lipids
13:06 Conclusion

title: Designing Nanotechnology: Weaving Molecular Fabric
description:
Prof David Leigh and a team of chemists have woven molecules together into a fabric only 4 nanometers thick! This incredible feat of nanotechnology is based on some intriguing science. Learn about how it works, how it was designed, and what kinds of practical applications it might have.

If you are a scientist looking for a new way to share your exciting research with the world, send me an email! stuart [at] biocinematics.com
 
Read the research paper here: https://rdcu.be/ccki9 
August, D.P., Dryfe, R.A.W., Haigh, S.J. et al. Self-assembly of a layered two-dimensional molecularly woven fabric. Nature 588, 429‚Äì435 (2020). https://doi.org/10.1038/s41586-020-3019-9

The assembly and analysis animation clips were funded by the Engineering and Physical Sciences Research Council (EPSRC; EP/P027067/1) and the European Research Council (ERC; Advanced Grant no. 786630)

Watch the "Making of" video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=77IXHb574KQ

Please consider SUBSCRIBING to watch more science/biology animations. https://www.youtube.com/biocinematics

1:50 Assembly
3:31 How to Design Nanotechnology
7:14 Practical Applications
10:38 Conclusion

title: Diffusion: How Molecules Actually Move
description:
Diffusion is a simple description of how molecules move, but at the nanoscale there's more going on. Can the Kinetic Molecular Theory predict where that CO2 molecule will go?
üëâ Want to support Biocinematics? https://www.patreon.com/biocinematics üëç

Teaching topics: Diffusion, kinetic molecular theory, dynamic equilibrium

title: The Pinball Machine of Science: Observing the Invisible
description:
What's the secret of the pinball machine of science? And what can the island of human knowledge teach us about how science has developed?
üëâ Want to support Biocinematics? https://www.patreon.com/biocinematics‚Äã üëç

Teaching topics: scientific process, indirect observation, data collection, history of science

title: Are you REALLY a Carbon Based Life Form?
description:
Are you really a carbon based life form? What is carbon anyway? And what are you actually made out of?
üëâ Want to support Biocinematics? https://www.patreon.com/biocinematics üëç

Teaching topics: Atoms, elements, the periodic table, carbon and other elements of life, simple molecules, biomolecules

The first in a series of 3D animated videos about human biology and biochemistry. Please consider SUBSCRIBING to watch future videos in the series. 

Errata: At 0:58, there should be three more zeroes (27, not 24) to make 7 octillion. Oops!

See References and Behind the Scenes at: https://biocinematics.squarespace.com/blog/2019/6/25/are-you-really-a-carbon-based-life-form

title: A Programmable Molecular Robot
description:
Scientists at the University of Manchester have developed a molecular machine capable of producing different stereoisomers, depending on the sequence of chemical reagents added. This animation uses a metaphorical representation to show how the molecular robot processes a substrate molecule.

Article: https://www.nature.com/articles/nature23677

Animation created for Prof. David Leigh (¬© 2017).

Music Credit:
Artist: Musicalwave
Title: Digital Technology
https://www.hooksounds.com

title: The Tightest Molecular Knot
description:
Scientists at the University of Manchester have synthesized the tightest knotted structure ever created. This animation uses a metaphorical representation to show how the molecule was synthesized.

Article: http://science.sciencemag.org/content/355/6321/159

Animation created for Prof. David Leigh (¬© 2017).

Music Credit:
Artist: D. J. Pinto
Title: All My Friends
https://www.hooksounds.com

title: Molecular Visualization: Principles and Practice
description:
This presentation was originally given at the 2016 Association of Medical Illustrators annual conference in Atlanta, Georgia. Visit https://sciencevis.ca/ to learn more.
This work was funded by the NSF and SSHRC of Canada.
This work is presented here by Stuart Jantzen courtesy of the Science Visualization Lab, University of Toronto in collaboration with Harvard Medical School.
